Z-Wave is a low power, low bandwidth, protocol for home automation devices - mostly sensors, switches, and light controls. [Click here](https://home-assistant.io/docs/z-wave/) for details on how to use it in Home Assistant, and the limitations of the Z-Wave mesh network.

[The XY problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XY_problem) is asking about your attempted solution rather than your actual problem. This leads to enormous amounts of wasted time and energy, both on the part of people asking for help, and on the part of those providing help.
The problem occurs when people get stuck on what they believe is the solution and are unable to step back and explain the issue in full.

```shell
$ sudo su -s /bin/bash homeassistant
$ cd /home/homeassistant/.homeassistant/deps
$ rm -rf aiohttp*
$ pip3 install --upgrade aiohttp==1.3.3 -t .
```

If you have missing dependencies in your logs use 
`sudo pip3 install` followed by name of missing dependency
for example:
```
ERROR (MainThread) [homeassistant.setup] Not initializing recorder because could not install dependency sqlalchemy==1.1.6
```
you would use the following command:
```shell
$ sudo pip3 install sqlalchemy==1.1.6
```

To activate your virtual environment, run these commands at your shell prompt as your main/default user (i.e. **pi** user):
```shell
$ sudo systemctl stop \"home*assistant*\"
$ sudo su -s /bin/bash homeassistant
$ source /srv/homeassistant/bin/activate
$ cd /home/homeassistant/.homeassistant
```
If you need to install any python packages for components, you can now do so with:
```shell
$ pip3 install yourcomponent
```

If you are using a RPI, you can use `sudo ncdu` to get a graphical tool to help sort and search for files that are taking up space on your pi. For me, the biggest offender is usually log files. Specifically for me, `homebridge.log`.

If you want to test out your MQTT install from your pi, first install [the client](https://mosquitto.org/2013/01/mosquitto-debian-repository/) and then use the following command to subscribe to all topics on your server:
```shell
$ mosquitto_sub -h IP_ADDRESS -u 'pi' -P 'raspberry' -t '#' -v
```

Discovery shouldn't be run in a production environment. Relying on discovery leaves the possibility that something may be missed or may be configured differently when it returns.

It is recommended to turn discovery on only to find new devices and retrieve the required information so that you can manually configure the devices.

The **[input_number](https://home-assistant.io/components/input_number/)** component allows the user to define values that can be controlled via the frontend and can be used within conditions of automation. The frontend can display a slider, or a numeric input box. Changes to the slider or numeric input box generate state events. These state events can be utilized as `automation` triggers as well.
```yaml
# Example configuration.yaml entry
input_number:
  slider1:
    name: Slider
    initial: 30
    min: -20
    max: 35
    step: 1```

If you're having problems with your updates to your configuration:
* Check the [troubleshooting steps](https://home-assistant.io/docs/configuration/troubleshooting/)
* Check your log file - remembering you may need to set [logger](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/logger#default) to `info` or `debug`
* Explain what the problem you're having is - [sharing](https://paste.ubuntu.com/) configuration, errors, and logs

A very simple yet powerful utility to help ease headaches when building up your Home Assistant configuration files.

Simply run this at your shell prompt to install hassctl:
```bash
$ sudo curl -o /usr/local/bin/hassctl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dale3h/hassctl/master/hassctl && sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/hassctl
```
For more information, please visit the `hassctl` project page: <https://github.com/dale3h/hassctl>
Use https://hastebin.com/ to share configuration files or log files.

Easily send files/text to hastebin.com from your CLI.

**Installation:**
```shell
$ pip3 install haste-client
```
***Note:** `sudo` might be required in some cases.*

**Example Usage (File):**
```shell
$ haste configuration.yaml
https://hastebin.com/netidofibu
```
**Example Usage (Stream/Pipe):**
```shell
$ cat configuration.yaml | haste
https://hastebin.com/netidofibu
```

You should automate, outside of Home Assistant, taking backups of your configuration, multiple times per day, using a tool that will track and store different versions, as well as creating a bootable backup if you're using a Raspberry Pi series computer. Options include rpi-clone (for bootable backups), rsnapshot (for backups within your home network), and rclone (for online backups).

Not sure which install you're using? If you have [`system_health`](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/system_health) enabled you can check _Configuration -> Info_, or see the following.

* If you're using HassOS, flashed an image, or booted a VM with an image you're using <#330990055533576204>

* If you installed Linux and then ran a script to install HA _and_ have add-ons then you have <#330944238910963714>

* If you're running `docker` commands or use a Docker manager and have _no add-ons_ then you have <#449717345808547842>

* Finally, if you use `pip` to install or upgrade you have <#551864459891703809>

5 Rules for better support:
```
1. Be very specific about the issue/problem you are facing (A problem clearly stated is a problem half solved)
2. Absolutely NO negative comments or thoughts about individuals, developers or the community
3. Read the documentation (RTFM). It is an open source product, you are allowed to contribute, but not whine
4. Every setup is unique in its own way. Share your config, code, logs and other relevant info via hastebin.com
5. Keep the channel live by being friendly, offer help where you can, learn when you can't!
```

To enable packages, add `packages: !include_dir_named packages` to your `configuration.yaml` so that it looks similar to this:
```yaml
homeassistant:
  name: Home
  latitude: !secret home_latitude
  ...
  packages: !include_dir_named packages
```
***Important:** The `packages:` line **must** be nested under `homeassistant:`!*

For more information on packages, please refer to the packages docs: <https://home-assistant.io/docs/configuration/packages/>

[YAML](https://home-assistant.io/docs/configuration/yaml/) is the mark up language used by Home Assistant, consistent indenting (two spaces per level) is key. [Here](http://thomasloven.com/blog/2018/08/YAML-For-Nonprogrammers/) is a primer, and [this](https://yaml-multiline.info/) explains multi-line templates. For validating YAML see [YAML Lint](http://www.yamllint.com/).
[Glance cards](https://www.home-assistant.io/lovelace/glance/) are very compact

The monster card was repalced by [auto entities](https://github.com/thomasloven/lovelace-auto-entities) which is a magical type of card. Because it's dynamic if you're smart about it, you can have one card that adapts and that you don't need to touch when adding new entities & sensors to your setup. Supports both inclusion and exclusion filters with wildcard for `entity_id`

[Don't ask to ask](https://dontasktoask.com/), just ask your question. Then people can answer when they're around.

When you do ask a question, try to provide as much background detail as possible. Ask yourself these questions first so that others don't have to:

1. *What version of the Home Assistant are you running? (remember, _last_ isn't a version)*
2. *What exactly are you trying to do that won't work?*
3. *Is the problem uniform or erratic?*
4. *What's the exact error message?*
5. *When did it arise?*
6. *What exactly don't you \"get\"?*
7. *Can you [share](https://paste.ubuntu.com/) sample code, ideally with line errors where the error occurs?*

**Before You Ask**
[How To Ask Questions The Smart Way](<http://www.catb.org/esr/faqs/smart-questions.html)

Before asking a technical question in our channels, please do the following:

1. Try to find an answer by searching the [archives of the forum](https://community.home-assistant.io/)
2. Try to find an answer by searching [the Web](https://www.google.com/)
3. Try to find an answer by reading [the manual](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/)
4. Try to find an answer by reading [the FAQ](https://www.home-assistant.io/faq/)
5. Try to find an answer by inspection or experimentation.
6. Try to find an answer by asking a skilled friend.
7. If you're a programmer, try to find an answer by reading [the source code](https://github.com/home-assistant/home-assistant)

When you ask your question, display the fact that you have done these things first; this will help establish that you're not being a lazy sponge and wasting people's time. Better yet, display what you have learned from doing these things. We like answering questions for people who have demonstrated they can learn from the answers.
Please use [imgur](https://imgur.com/) or other image sharing web sites, and share the link here.

**404** Error for docker usually is a result of one of these things:

- The image tag you are trying to use does not exist (if this is the case you will see the word 'manifest' in the error)

- There is not enough space left on the device to download the new container.

As an alternative to HA built-in bluetooth tracking, [the monitor script](https://github.com/andrewjfreyer/monitor) uses separate devices, usually [Pi Zeroes](https://www.raspberrypi.org/products/raspberry-pi-zero/), to track bluetooth devices.
It uses MQTT topics to relay device status messages to HA. See [this forum thread](https://community.home-assistant.io/t/monitor-reliable-multi-user-distributed-bluetooth-occupancy-presence-detection/68505) for more.

Key things are the version of _Home Assistant_ you're running, how you installed it (Home Assistant OS, Supervised, Container, Core), the exact component you're having problems with (eg _Nest climate_ rather than _climate_), and details of the problem (ideally with any error message in full).

[Home Assistant](https://www.home-assistant.io/hassio/) (previously called Hass.io) is _one of_ the ways you can [install](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/installation/) **Home Assistant Core**. You're still running Home Assistant Core.

There are three Zigbee options with Home Assistant (regardless of how you install it). These are:

[deCONZ](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/deconz/) is relatively stable and mature with its own UI. It can run in an add-on, in a Docker container, or natively. Known working devices are documented, and how to request support for a new device is documented too (you can't add unsupported devices yourself).

[zha](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/zha/) is actively developed as part of Home Assistant Core, using the zigpy stack, the UI also being part of Home Assistant. There is no list of supported devices, as any standards compliant device should work. Devices that require extra support are listed, and adding unsupported devices is documented (you can't add unsupported devices yourself).

[Zigbee2MQTT](https://www.zigbee2mqtt.io/) is very actively developed and can run in an add-on, in a Docker container, and natively, with no native UI. It uses MQTT for control and configuration, but there are third party UIs. The known working devices are well documented (which usually includes how to pair them so you don't have to find the manual), and adding unsupported devices is also documented.

**Rule #6:** Please do not post codewalls (longer than ***15 lines***) - use sites such as https://hasteb.in/, https://paste.ubuntu.com/, or others.

*Please take the time now to review all of the rules and references in <#331130181102206976>.*

Looking for advice about a device to buy? Remember to provide guidance on:
* Which country you're in
* What your budget is
* What protocols you prefer (eg Zigbee, WiFi, Z-Wave)
* Any features you want (such as power monitoring, dimming, etc)
Hass.io was the old name for the appliance like install option, that _uses_ Docker. It is now simply called _Home Assistant OS_ (see <#330990055533576204>).

Integrations _integrate_ Home Assistant with devices or services, or provide functionality within Home Assistant. Add-ons provide additional software or services, which an integration could possibility integrate with. Add-ons are for Home Assistant OS and Supervised only, other install methods can install software other ways.

Running Home Assistant in a venv on Windows isn't recommended. Not all integrations may work, because some Python packages aren't available. You should consider [using Docker](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/installation/docker/#windows) instead, or running on a Linux host.

[deCONZ](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/deconz) by dresden elektronik is a software that communicates with ConBee/RaspBee Zigbee gateways and exposes Zigbee devices that are connected to the gateway. Our <#551843655682490399> channel is a good place to ask about using it with Home Assistant, but they also have their own [Discord server](https://discord.gg/RNTwa6d).

[ESPHome](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/esphome/) is a system to control your ESP8266/ESP32. You can find their [documentation here](https://esphome.io/), and get help here in the <#444529271806099486> channel. They have their own [Discord server too](https://discord.gg/KhAMKrd).

[AppDaemon](https://appdaemon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) is a loosely coupled, multithreaded, sandboxed python execution environment for writing automation apps. It uses the Home Assistant API (or MQTT) to communicate with HA. You can get help at [their Discord server](https://discord.gg/Mx5qafB).

[Zigbee2MQTT](https://www.zigbee2mqtt.io/) is a Zigbee gateway that uses MQTT to communicate with HA and supports a range of TI chipset based controllers. Our <#551843655682490399> channel is a good place to ask about using it with Home Assistant, but they also have their own [Discord server](https://discord.gg/NyseBeK).
Some [integrations](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations) are added with YAML, some in the UI. Check the documentation for your integration to see which method it uses.
A learning experience is one of those things that says, _'You know that thing you just did? Don't do that.'_

An add-on is a Docker container with tweaks to allow it to be configured in the Supervisor UI. It is only available in the Supervised install since if you've used any other install method you're able to install software already.
Various settings are hidden unless your user profile has _Advanced mode_ enabled. These include some add-ons, the Lovelace _Resources_ menu, server control options, and more.
You can find his config lurking [in the darkness](https://github.com/atxbyea/HA-Config).

To test an automation there's three stages you can follow. Testing the action, the condition and action, and the whole automation:

1) Use _Developer tools_ (<:devtools:619094051878207520>)-> _States_ to find the automation, click <:info:333726950717784064> and then push Execute
2) Use _Developer tools_ -> _Services_ and call `automation.trigger` on the automation with `skip_condition: false`
3) Use _Developer tools_ -> _States_ to find the trigger entity, click the name, then change the state (at the top) to something that'll trigger the automation before pushing _Set State_
Please don't say _I have an error_ or describe an error. Share the whole actual error message so we can help you.

Not sure which install method to use, here's a [simple summary](https://www.home-assistant.io/faq/ha-vs-hassio/):

* [Home Assistant](https://www.home-assistant.io/hassio/installation/): All in one solution with the ability to install other software though the UI (called add-ons), and manage backups in the UI (called snapshots). Installs as an image or on top of Debian/Ubuntu.
* [Docker](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/installation/docker/): For those already at comfortable with running on Docker. You install other software and manage backups yourself. Consider another option if you're using Windows or macOS.
* [venv](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/installation/raspberry-pi/): For those Linux admins or other crazy folks who want to run bare metal. You do everything, including rebuilding your venv with new Python versions. Don't try this method on Windows.

TL/DR: Use what works for you.

Generally, don't tag people to ask for help - it comes across as bad manners, you’re demanding somebody answers you. It’s different if you’re thanking somebody, obviously. If you do tag somebody keep it polite and respectful. Remember that everybody is a volunteer, and nobody _has_ to help you, and people may block you.

Similarly, please don’t DM (direct message) people asking for help. It also comes across as demanding, and means that others can’t learn from what you do.

Finally, please keep tagging people in replies to a minimum. That too can become annoying very quickly and should be used only when it's necessary (such as if it's been a long time, or there's multiple conversations going on).
'Latest' is not a version number. Please provide the actual version number.

**Oh boy!** :scream:

`database disk image is malformed` tells you that your database file has been corrupted :cry:
But do not worry, there is an easy fix :tada:
1. Delete the `home-assistant_v2.db` file in the same folder as `configuration.yaml`
2. Restart Home Assistant.

_Sidenote: this will cause you to lose all your history, but it's broken anyway, so just do it._

**Disabling Custom Header**

This is one of the first things mentioned on CH's [Forum post](https://community.home-assistant.io/t/custom-header), [Github readme](https://github.com/maykar/custom-header/blob/master/README.md), [Docs](https://maykar.github.io/custom-header), [important notes](https://maykar.github.io/custom-header/#intro/notes), and UI Editor.

Every option that can remove your ability to access UI elements is marked with a warning in the docs and UI editor with a link to [this page explaining how to disable CH](https://maykar.github.io/custom-header/#intro/notes).

[Custom Header](https://github.com/maykar/custom-header) adds enhancements and customization options to Home Assistant's Lovelace header. Features include: styling/hiding of all header elements, dynamic changes with Jinja templates, per user/device configs, compact mode, footer mode, split mode, and more.

2. Search [community forum](https://community.home-assistant.io/)
3. Try Googling _Home Assistant MYDEVICE_ or _MYDEVICE Python_

To enable debug for the deCONZ integration in Home-Assistant, add the following to your configuration.yaml:```yaml
logger:
  default: info
  logs:
    pydeconz: debug
    homeassistant.components.deconz: debug
```

If you have a feature request for the frontend you can open [one here](https://github.com/home-assistant/frontend/issues), for Home Assistant itself please [post on the forum](https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests/13). All other feature requests should be made to the developer of that custom card/component.

There is no universal _best_ [weather integration](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations#weather). Which one works best _for you_ depends on where you live - try them all and see which is generally the most accurate.
